text: hi everyone anthony fantano here
internet's busiest music nerd
and it's time for a review of the new
toxic holocaust
album chemistry of consciousness
toxic holocaust is a metal outfit that
right now i believe
is portland-based and is fronted by
singer-songwriter and
multi-instrumentalist
joel grind this is their fifth
full-length studio lp and for years this
project has been dropping music that has
been a pretty
seamless combination of thrash metal
punk rock
a bit of black metal which was placed
into the equation ever so subtly
overdose of death being an lp that i
think brought some of toxic holocaust's
most well-crafted songs yet
to the table ferocity variety and detail
in the songs on this record and then
there was conjure and command that
dropped a few years ago
which showed toxic holocaust bringing a
better recording
to the table the band sounding much
heavier thicker
just probably the most visceral
album to come out of this project and
joel really subtracted the
black metal influences from this record
in a big way and just sort of stuck
simply to the thrash metal and the punk
sounds
that they had been playing with for the
most part up to that point anyway
there's no question
on this album joel really simplified the
toxic holocaust formula
to some of its most aggressive just
no bs elements and that sort of left me
wondering or
fearing that maybe the next album would
entertain me a bit less
because there would surely be a lack of
surprises on it i do kind of feel like
that
is happening here to at least some
degree
i guess the recording and the production
on this record are a bit
thicker a bit more distorted joel's
vocal delivery is
roughly the same if toxic holocaust goes
in any direction with this album
i think they actually boil things down
even
further because many of the heavy slower
or more ominous moments
from the project's previous lp conjuring
command
are sort of subtracted and even though
that means that
on this lp you're not really waiting
around for the songs to start kicking
ass it's just one non-stop ass kicking
fest
what that has also created here is an
album that to me feels a lot less
dynamic than
its predecessors toxic holocaust really
leaves no room
for finesse whatsoever and they really
lay the weight of this album's success
onto the guitar riffs which
are by no means bad they're executed
very well again the grooves are hard
hitting
they're infectious but toxic holocaust
guitar riffs don't exactly have a track
record
of being incredibly original
or distinct for me on toxic holocaust's
previous stuff
the riffs and the beats were just a
really good foundation
for some more interesting things that
brought this base
flavor and that would be some
interesting lyrical concepts that were
grim or dark or socially aware some
guitar leads or melodies that were
memorable
maybe an interesting bridge and the song
structure or a song that was kind of a
coming out a left field and a in a
darker or slower tone or something
these variants don't introduce
themselves enough on this album to make
the entire listening experience
memorable there are highlights on here
though like the sort of slow
and feedback backfilled outro to the
closing track here or the ominous guitar
arpeggios on the song rat eater which
opened the song
up there are some refrain some choruses
on here that are pretty memorable like
acid fuzz the guitar solo was pretty
badass on that track too
and then we have some lyrical ideas like
deny the truth where
obviously we have joel talking about in
the lyrics this
blatant refusal to believe what is true
and sort of right in front of your face
just self-impose ignorance and then
there's the track mk
ultra which i'm not sure how many thrash
metal songs there
are out there about top secret
government projects but
this is one of the few one of the proud
and honestly throughout this lp
there's not really one huge moment where
i feel like it falters or joel comes
through with a horrible song
the production is crushing the riffs
again
passable the album is fast paced there
is an element of just
adrenaline pumping madness to the way
these guitars and drums work together i
liked this album but i'm just not seeing
what toxic holocaust is doing here
that they haven't already done better on
their previous releases
so i'm feeling a light to decent six
on this thing transition but if you've
given this a
toxic holocaust lp you listen what did
you think of it did you love it
hate it why what do you think i should
review next
and uh that's it anthony fantano
toxic holocaust chemistry
forever
